title: 1975 AMC Gremlin: The Legend Revisited! - Ignition Ep. 129

comments.text: Hello everyone, this is my 1975 PIECE OF SHIT!!!!!!!!!!!﻿
comments.author: marcus tohmas

comments.text:
Drove my 76 Gremlin from St Louis to Chicago to see Pink Floyd. Never 
missed a beat. Also drove it from St Louis to the Smokey Mountains and 
never missed a beat. Actually it never failed me. It's inovative features 
were disc brakes, radial tires and ran on unleaded gas.﻿
comments.author: Tom Wagner

comments.text:
My Aunt had a 1975 or 76.  It was white with a big blue stripe.  She loved 
that car and kept it in show room condition for about 10 years!  I want to 
say she put about 90,000 miles on it before she sold it.  Lot's of 
childhood memories in that car.  One thing I remember was a knob on the A/C 
that was for temperature control.  If you turned it to the far right there 
was a setting that said "desert only".  I never got up the nerve to turn it 
to this setting!  Thanks for bringing back the memories!﻿
comments.author: Brent Audi

comments.text:
I stumbled upon this car review and stuck around because of the reviewers 
funny comments. Great review and the steering wheel hit for glove box open 
feature was the best!﻿

comments.author: gothnate

comments.text:
These cars obviously were built for basic transportation. Dropping the kids 
at school, running to the hardware store, etc. Not cross country touring or 
blazing through a curved freeway onramp at 90 mph. They served their 
purpose at a good price, period.﻿

comments.text: HaHa conceived on a BARF BAG!!﻿

lol, no one in 20-30 years will ever want/care about a Accent.  LIke the

comments.author: RCPro Driver

comments.text:
You didn't mention the Gremlin X or the Gremlin XR. 301 V8 or a 403 V8. You 
could even get it with a Borg Warner 4 speed. Now talk about a fun car to 
drive. Holy, don't feed the Gremlin.....or it's gonna bit ya.lol.﻿
comments.author: imonetwistedtech

comments.text:
I owned one of these (1971 brown color no carpet and manual shift) and can 
honestly say I loved it. I think it was its simplicity, and lack of caring 
about conforming to what was cool or desired. It also was a fantastically 
reliable car in its day and would work hard with the torque it had for its 
weight; it did whatever I asked of it. I miss it.﻿
comments.author: Windy Run

comments.text:
I'm not sure anyone does like these cars? If it wasn't for a cameo in 
Waynes World these shit heaps would be long forgotten for the fuck ups on 
wheels they are﻿
comments.author: EXILE ROTORSPORT NZ

comments.text:
Imagine if you could somehow put the cam profiles and heads, GDI, ignition, 
and mild boost tech of a 200+ HP moden small displacement inline 4 onto one 
of those slant sixes or V-8s available in an AMX, replace the original 
springs and shocks with modern variable rate ones, tighten it up with 
swaybars, cross-bracing and low profile tires.

I think it would be a whole different beast than what is seen here in a 
rather tired out car in it's original form.

What made those old 1970s and early 1980s cars lousy was the way emissions 
controls were implemented back then. Even the muscle cars from that 
timeframe had craptastic numbers in stock form.

Thing with these cars back in thier day is they were easy to tweak as you 
had bigger engine crammed into a smaller chassis to start out with. It 
wasn't worth leaving stock as it seems to be in this case here.﻿
comments.author: pauljs75

comments.text:
Ur not roadkill
﻿
comments.author: donovan cooper

comments.text:
I had a '75 when I lived in Florida. I lived in an area that had some 
flooding and frequent rains. At the first moment of moisture, it would 
stall. Then up went the hood and a douse of W-D40 on the distributor and 
off we went. I loved that car, named Kermit, for its color. Was it a great 
car? NO! Would I own another one? YES. I wish I never sold it. It had 
character. And the things wrong with it are now easy repairs. I really hate 
new cars and wish I had any dozen of my old ones back.﻿
comments.author: 3RayJ3

comments.text:
Come on face it. It was a piece of shit and it pales in comparison even to 
Todays Hyundai Accent. And it was equivalent to $12 000 USD Today? What a 
fucking Ripoff !!﻿

The "Weather Eye" name comes from Nash(-Kelvinator), which used this name 
for its air conditioning from at least the 40s.﻿

comments.author: Grunchy

comments.text:
A guy I used to chum around with about 35 years ago had a beat-up '74 
Gremlin and he put a small-block Chevy V8 engine in the car and mated it to 
a manual transmission with a Hurst shifter kit, and then he added some huge 
mag wheels to the back. It was the silliest, craziest thing, but it would 
go like snot, and it earned him a fairly serious speeding ticket when he 
was visiting Port Huron, Michigan one day.﻿
comments.author: Steve Struthers

comments.text: My Parents had one when I was a kid!﻿

comments.text: the lesson here is ..if road kill loans it to you its gonna have issuses﻿
comments.author: cartmanrlsusall

comments.text:
Buddy of mine had the SB V8 version w/3 SPD manual and the thing was a very 
scary ride, posi trac and all. One of the few muscle cars that was 
intimidating. Tough to keep it in a straight line.﻿
comments.author: Lil Hooch

comments.text:
Could Americans make 6.0L engine that puts out 50 HP tho? That's a

comments.text: Much better than a Pinto or a Vega!﻿
comments.author: John Hiram

My Parents had one of these. We would get all 6 of us in it. We were small

comments.author: Shane freeman

comments.text:
It's a little unfair to apply modern day standards to  a 40 year old used 
car. Why not do a comparison to a 40 year old Pinto or Vega, if you can 
find one? Also, if I am not mistaken, the 232CID engine was the base for an 
Offenhauser racing engine. In street form, this 232CID engine with a cam. 
dual carbs and headers would produce over 400hp.
And......Let's not forget the Gremlin X, the V8 version.﻿

The Amc six is the reason that car was loved.   Had more  power than V8

comments.author: PW Craig

comments.text:
I had 3 gremlins, and they were not bad cars. Wish I had my '72 custom one

comments.author: ferlenarab

comments.text:
My dad was an accountant and worked for Dollar Rent-A-Car in the 70s. He 
could take a car anytime he needed one and when his own car, a massive 
Mercury Park Lane was in the shop he would usually bring home one of those 
Gremlins. They really weren't bad little cars for their day. AMC actually 
offered that car with an eight cylinder engine that performed pretty well. 
If I remember right there was even a blue jean inspired denim interior as a 
custom option.﻿

comments.author: ryfin2000

comments.text:
Had a Hornet wagon with 304cid V8, and Gucci interior. Nearly identical 
interior, and fit and finish was about the same. Fitted with time-delay 
wipers, "desert climate control", obligatory 8-track, and a host of other 
ridiculous doo-dads, it was - in hindsight - a terrible car, but at the 
time, the closest thing to a space-ship an early teen driver and car 
enthusiast could hope for.﻿
comments.author: Chris Ice

comments.text:

bad modern cars are so filled with electronic crap they've become nearly 
unaffordable.﻿

comments.author: journeyquest1

comments.text:
It was my first car. Looked just like that one. Mine had a 304 V8, it took

comments.author: iamdemocratic1

comments.text:
My first car was a 1977 Gremlin 2-Liter....biggest lemon I ever owned, but 
I love it to this day....plenty of head and leg room....four speed was fun 
to play with....thought the German engineered motor would have been the 
best thing to happen to AMC....it was not!!!!....I still have possession of 
its mortal remains in the woods at  a friends house....If some low life had 
not broken out the back glass and tried to put a brick through the 
windshield, I might have tried to get it restored.....﻿
comments.author: Prentiss Powell

comments.text:
That Gremlin is actually a 1976. It was the only year to have round 
parking/marker lights. (OK, I caught your "confession" when you mentioned 
the 1975 car has a 1976 grille.) Inline engines with both the intake and 
exhaust manifolds sharing the bolts and studs weren't uncommon. You've been 
around too many cross-flow OHC designs that are a PITA to work on. But I 
enjoyed your video all the same.﻿
comments.author: Rick S

comments.text:
I love these cars! My parents had an AMC Hornet when I was growing up, 
those engines were sorta junky, if I remember right, when they finally got 
rid of it after owning it for 9 years (bought it new in 74'), the engine 
had less than 150K on it and was on it's last leg. Dad had to replace the 
motor in it from my grampa's auto salvage yard in order to sell it!﻿
